parts: Make a table detailing operations on Python dataframes, specifying whether it modifies or does not modify the original dataframe

Here is a table detailing common operations on pandas DataFrames, specifying whether they modify the original DataFrame or return a new one:

| **Operation**                     | **Modifies Original DataFrame?** | **Description** |
|------------------------------------|--------------------------------|----------------|
| `df['new_col'] = values`          | ✅ Yes                         | Adds or modifies a column. |
| `df.drop(columns=['col'])`        | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame without the specified column. |
| `df.drop(columns=['col'], inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes               | Removes the column from `df`. |
| `df.drop(index=5)`                | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame without the specified row. |
| `df.drop(index=5, inplace=True)`  | ✅ Yes                         | Removes the row from `df`. |
| `df.rename(columns={'old': 'new'})` | ❌ No                         | Returns a new DataFrame with renamed columns. |
| `df.rename(columns={'old': 'new'}, inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes      | Renames columns in place. |
| `df.sort_values(by='col')`        | ❌ No                          | Returns a sorted DataFrame. |
| `df.sort_values(by='col', inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes               | Sorts `df` in place. |
| `df.set_index('col')`             | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with the specified column as the index. |
| `df.set_index('col', inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes                     | Sets the index in place. |
| `df.reset_index()`                | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with the default integer index. |
| `df.reset_index(inplace=True)`    | ✅ Yes                         | Resets the index in place. |
| `df.replace({'old': 'new'})`      | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with replaced values. |
| `df.replace({'old': 'new'}, inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes            | Replaces values in place. |
| `df.fillna(value)`                | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with missing values filled. |
| `df.fillna(value, inplace=True)`  | ✅ Yes                         | Fills missing values in place. |
| `df.dropna()`                     | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame without missing values. |
| `df.dropna(inplace=True)`         | ✅ Yes                         | Removes missing values in place. |
| `df.duplicated()`                 | ❌ No                          | Returns a Series indicating duplicate rows. |
| `df.drop_duplicates()`            | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame without duplicate rows. |
| `df.drop_duplicates(inplace=True)` | ✅ Yes                         | Removes duplicate rows in place. |
| `df.append(other_df)` (deprecated) | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with rows from another DataFrame. |
| `pd.concat([df, other_df])`       | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame by concatenating DataFrames. |
| `df.merge(other_df, on='col')`    | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame from merging two DataFrames. |
| `df.groupby('col')`               | ❌ No                          | Returns a GroupBy object for aggregation. |
| `df.pivot(index, columns, values)` | ❌ No                         | Returns a pivoted DataFrame. |
| `df.melt(id_vars, value_vars)`    | ❌ No                          | Returns a melted DataFrame. |
| `df.apply(func, axis=1)`          | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame or Series with function applied. |
| `df.map(func)`                    | ❌ No                          | Returns a transformed Series. |
| `df.astype({'col': dtype})`       | ❌ No                          | Returns a new DataFrame with changed data types. |
| `df.memory_usage(deep=True)`      | ❌ No                          | Returns memory usage of the DataFrame. |

Let me know if you need more details! 🚀
